meta.title: Woke: A Guide to Social Justice
meta.author: Titania McGrath
meta.publisher: Constable, an imprint of Little, Brown Book Group

parts.title: Titania's Woke Journey 🚨✨
parts.body: Titania McGrath introduces herself as a rad ical intersectionalist poet with a gift for social justice. She claims her wokeness is innate, comparing herself to Joan of Arc. Titania shares stories of performing slam poetry and armed peaceful protests, expressing disdain for patriarchal constructs in academia. She presents herself as a guiding force for those struggling to keep up with modern social justice concepts, aiming to mold them into more "woke" individuals. Her writing style is satirical, bold, and touches on themes of identity, feminism, and privilege.

parts.title: Embracing Social Media Activism
parts.body: In early 2018, I was inspired by online activists to become more active on social media to spread awareness about social justice. The internet, the new weapon of choice, is where modern-day "keyboard warriors" make a greater impact than historical figures like Martin Luther King. My newfound activism led to gaining thousands of followers, whom I prefer to call disciples. However, being a woman online exposed me to abuse and criticism, especially regarding my poetry. I've been accused of being shrill and humorless, highlighting the underlying sexism and resistance to ideas that don't conform to the status quo.

parts.title: Women, Misogyny, and Empowerment
parts.body: The author discusses their frustrations with gender inequality and internalized misogyny. They highlight the need for women to make empowering career choices to redress imbalances. The text criticizes Donald Trump's election victory, attributing it to women who have internalized misogyny. They quote Linda Sarsour wishing to "take away" vaginas from women like Brigitte Gabriel who disagree with feminist views. The author encourages ignoring both men and women who oppose feminism as either misogynists or have internalized misogyny. Criticism is directed at three influential women – Christina Hoff Sommers, Camille Paglia, and Ella Whelan, whom the author labels as dangerous figures not deserving a platform for their opposition to modern feminist ideals. Each woman provides a quote critiquing trigger warnings, safe spaces, and the view of women as weak. These quotes reflect their disapproval of current feminist movements for being infantilizing and weak. The author dismissively calls them hateful bitches for questioning feminist doctrines.

parts.title: Intersectional Feminism and Islam
parts.body: In this segment, intersectional feminism and Islam are explored. The author emphasizes the importance of treating Muslims with care, especially due to increased stereotypes and biases. They argue that Muslims are often unjustly scapegoated since 9/11, and highlight the misconception that Islam and feminism are incompatible. The piece criticizes the reluctance to accept expressions of Islamic culture like the veil, and emphasizes how the West needs to address its own cultural failings, like the refusal of a Belfast bakery to support gay marriage, before judging Islam. The author suggests that Islamophobic opposition to hijabs and burkas is unfounded. Despite terrorist acts, the author believes focusing on medieval Christian wrongdoings, like the Crusades, is more appropriate than highlighting modern Islamic extremism. The section also notes the author’s view that criticisms of Islam often stem from ignorance of the intersectionality theory and the societal backlash following jihadist terrorism. Finally, some right-wing groups claim that Islamic countries mistreat women and LGBTQIA+ people, but the author insists these are progressive misunderstandings of Islamic society.

parts.title: The End of Poetry and Rise of Wokeness
parts.body: This book concludes that poetry and art have reached their zenith with Titania McGrath. Despite being frequently admired, they feel the weight of being misunderstood, particularly by men. They see their work as a tool for social justice, minority defense, and patriarchy dismantling rather than an ego-driven pursuit. McGrath calls for compulsory Gender Studies in schools to tackle patriarchal norms, advocating for wokeness over criticism like being labeled ‘Orwellian’. The objective is to eliminate all forms of bias and achieve a woke utopia.
